=== Racism === {{Advert|section|date=September 2018}} On 11 September 2018, AfriForum founded a unit against racism and hate speech. Roleplayers who have committed themselves to act as advisors on this unit include: Dr Frans Cronje, CEO of the Institute of Race Relations (IRR), The civil rights activist Rhoda Kadalie, Adv. Mark Oppenheimer, expert in freedom of speech and hate speech and Dr Llewellyn Curlewis, criminal law expert, explained the legal remedies available to citizens to fight racism.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/afriforum-launches-anti-racism-unit-20170911|title=AfriForum launches anti-racism unit|work=News24|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref>
AfriForum submitted criminal charges against two police officials and a former member of the South African National Defence Force (SANDF) in January 2018 after they used social media to incite farm attacks and/or romanticise violence against farmers and minorities. AfriForum says that these incidents can be considered a form of complicity by the South African government and that it urgently needs to be tackled by the police to ensure that those responsible are prosecuted. Mseleni Mogolwane Gwabeni, who is a member of the SAPS according to his Facebook profile, said on this social media platform “then we must continue to kill more of their farmers at least to make up for what they did to us [sic]”. Chris Gumotso, who works at the SAPS youth crime prevention desk according to his Facebook profile, placed the following on Facebook: “All white man…deserve to die…in future..f*©k u..Mr white man.” He also placed photos of firearms on his police desk on his profile with this quote: “I predict th civil war.. in mzansi…by 2019…take out ur guns…fighters coz Asijiki [sic].”<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.polity.org.za/article/afriforum-lays-criminal-charges-against-police-officials-2018-06-18|title=AfriForum lays criminal charges against police officials|work=Polity.org.za|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref>
In June 2017 AfriForum submitted criminal charges against a 100 social media users for incitement of violence.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://citizen.co.za/news/south-africa/1554475/afriforum-to-lay-charges-against-these-100-social-media-users/|title=AfriForum to lay charges against these 100 social media users|last=reporter|first=Citizen|work=The Citizen|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref>
AfriForum has been consistent in condemning both white on black and black on white racism. The organisation released media statements in which they address racist incidents involving amongst others Penny Sparrow,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/south-africans-have-double-standards-when-it-comes-to-racism-afriforum-20170216|title=South Africans have double standards when it comes to racism - AfriForum|work=News24|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref> Darren Scott,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ewn.co.za/2011/09/08/AfriForum-welcomes-Darren-Scotts-apology|title=AfriForum welcomes Darren Scott's apology|last=News|first=Eyewitness|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref> Dan Roodt,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/AfriForum-condemns-racist-Dan-Roodt-20141113|title=AfriForum condemns 'racist' Dan Roodt|date=2014-11-13|access-date=2018-09-26|work=News24}}</ref> Adam Catzavelos,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2018-08-22-afriforum-condemns-use-of-k-word-by-catzavelos-urges-consistency-in-condemnation-of-racism-from-all-sides/|title=AfriForum condemns use of k-word by Catzavelos‚ urges consistency in condemnation of racism from all sides|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref> and the Kommandokorps.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Kommandokorps-denies-racism-20120227|title=Kommandokorps denies racism|work=News24|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref> The organisation frequently condemns double standards in South Africa when it comes to dealing with racism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politics/vicki-momberg-sentencing-confirms-double-standards|title=Vicki Momberg: Absurd double standards being applied – AfriForum - POLITICS {{!}} Politicsweb|website=www.politicsweb.co.za|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref> {{primary-source-inline|date=September 2018}}
==Community affairs==
===Local government=== This department addresses municipal service delivery problems in over 125 towns and cities across South Africa.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
In order to achieve this goal, AfriForum attempts to establish partnerships with municipalities. The organisation allegedly submits wish lists to municipalities, and municipalities convert it into action plans to address issues. AfriForum says if municipalities do not cooperate in improving service delivery to residents, the organisation approaches courts to order municipalities to enforce service delivery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polity.org.za/article/afriforum-statement-by-afriforum-minority-civil-organisation-brings-application-to-retain-electricity-supply-to-klerksdorp-and-jouberton-22022013-2013-02-22|title=AfriForum: Statement by AfriForum, minority civil organisation, brings application to retain electricity supply to Klerksdorp and Jouberton (22/02/2013)|work=Polity.org.za}}</ref> {{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}}
An example of intervention by AfriForum in this regard, was the urgent order awarded to the organisation against the Vhembe District Municipality by the [[High Court]] in [[Pretoria]], forcing the municipality to supply water to [[Makhado]] residents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/afriforum-wins-fights-for-water-1.1394477|title=Afriforum wins fights for water|author=Independent Newspapers Online|work=Independent Online}}</ref> In a similar case in 2013, the North Gauteng High Court in Pretoria granted AfriForum an order stopping the Madibeng Municipality from cutting electricity supply to Hartbeespoort.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
In 2010 a legal team for AfriForum representing farmers in [[Zimbabwe]] won a court bid to sue Zimbabwe's government over its “cruel” and “vengeful” [[expropriation]] of South African-owned farms. In 2008 the regional court SADC tribunal ruled that Zimbabwe's [[land reform]] was illegal and racist, and that those who had suffered discrimination by having their farms expropriated had the right to compensation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/africa/afriforum-wins-first-round-in-zimbabwe-case-1.470355|title=Afriforum wins first round in Zimbabwe case|author=Independent Newspapers Online|work=Independent Online}}</ref>
AfriForum's local government interventions have been described positively, even by its critics.<ref name="news24DuPreez2016Hijacking"/>
===Community safety=== {{Advert section|date=May 2018}} AfriForum’s Community Safety Department participates in endeavours which promote the safety of citizens within communities. A large emphasis is placed on assisting communities and neighbourhoods to establish safety structures. Some of these structures include neighbourhood watches, farm watches, radio networks and community forums.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polity.org.za/article/afriforum-statement-by-reg-crewe-afriforum-head-of-community-safety-vryburg-launches-community-patrols-05112012-2012-11-05|title=AfriForum: Statement by Reg Crewe, Afriforum Head of Community Safety, Vryburg launches community patrols (05/11/2012)|work=Polity.org.za}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}}
In 2011 AfriForum commissioned Professor Rudolph Zinn of UNISA to conduct research into successful community safety structures in South Africa. The research has led to the compilation of a community safety handbook that has been implemented in all AfriForum branches countrywide. The department also focuses on the role of government and in particular that of law enforcement agencies, and acts as a pressure group so that citizens get the best safety and security possible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriforum.co.za/english/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/report-community-safety-networks.pdf|title=AfriForum|work=AfriForum}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}}
==Controversies== In 2015 AfriForum asserted that allegations of racism{{clarify|date=May 2018}} against Curro Foundation School are themselves racist. In a statement by the organisation's chair it was said "To portray an Afrikaans class being transported as class group falsely as racial segregation, is beyond absurd". An investigation into the matter came to the conclusion that the class was in fact segregated racially as was alleged because white parents had pressured the school.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/School-racism-allegations-are-racist-Afriforum-Youth-20150618|title=School racism allegations are 'racist' - Afriforum Youth|publisher=News24}}</ref>
A group of AfriForum protestors were found by judge AJ Donen to have engaged in "assault, sexual violence, sexual aggression and intimidation" at Stellenbosch University,<ref name="news24DuPreez2016Hijacking"/> and the organisation initiated a boycott of Afrikaans newspapers that reported on Potchefstroom students that gave the [[Nazi salute]] during their initiation.<ref name="news24DuPreez2016Hijacking"/>
In 2016 AfriForum supporters protested in Pretoria together with the political party [[Freedom Front Plus]]'s members because Steve Hofmeyr's scheduled event at Café Dudok, a restaurant in the Netherlands, was cancelled when the organisers were alerted of his alleged white supremacy by a left-wing group in Netherlands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/news/hofmeyr-defended-in-dutch-caf-snub-2028898|title=Hofmeyr defended in Dutch café snub|publisher=Daily News}}</ref>
In 2016 eight students affiliated with AfriForum youth wing were suspended from [[Stellenbosch University]] Student Representative Council (SRC) elections after allegations of campaign irregularities. Posters that they produced and hanged around the campus were removed after they were deemed controversial and harmful to other students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/8-afriforum-students-suspended-from-stellenbosch-src-elections-20160802|title=8 AfriForum students suspended from Stellenbosch SRC elections|publisher=News24}}</ref>
In May 2018, following criticism of Afriforum by a [[North-West University]] professor, Elmien du Plessis,<ref name="afriforumStatsDuPlessis">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/Columnists/GuestColumn/afriforums-own-farm-murder-stats-dont-support-their-claims-20180507|title=AfriForum's own farm murder stats don't support their claims|publisher=News24}}</ref> Afriforum's deputy CEO, Ernst Roets, posted a YouTube video where he quoted [[Victor Klemperer]], stating that "if the tables were turned after the Holocaust he "would have all the intellectuals strung up, and the professors three feet higher than the rest; they would be left hanging from the lamp posts for as long as was compatible with hygiene."<ref name="huffPoHevyWeightAttack">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2018/05/06/afriforum-heavyweight-launches-attack-on-academic-over-criticism-about-us-tour_a_23428355/|title=AfriForum Heavyweight Launches Attack On Academic Over Criticism About US Tour|date=6 May 2018|publisher=Huffington Post South Africa}}</ref> Following the video posting, du Plessis and her family received threats of violence.<ref name="huffPoProfThreatened">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2018/05/07/professor-threatened-after-afriforum-criticism-dont-get-too-comfortable-youre-next_a_23429098/|title=Professor Threatened After AfriForum Criticism: 'Don't Get Too Comfortable, You're Next'|date=8 May 2018|publisher= Huffington Post South Africa}}</ref><ref name="news24ThreatsViolenceHanging">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/varsity-prof-on-afriforums-angry-roets-threat-of-violence-hanging-not-acceptable-20180507|title=Varsity prof on AfriForum's 'angry' Roets: 'Threat of violence, hanging not acceptable'|publisher=News24}}</ref><ref name="habibHitsOutAfriforum">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/p2-academic-adam-habib-hits-out-at-disgusting-afriforum-leaders-20180510|title=Academic Adam Habib hits out at 'disgusting' AfriForum leaders|publisher=}}</ref> A petition condemning the threats against academics was subsequently circulated.<ref name="huffPocademicPetitionCirculated">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2018/05/14/petition-against-afriforum-over-threat-to-academics_a_23434037/|title=Petition Against AfriForum Over Threat To Academics|date=14 May 2018|publisher=Huffington Post South Africa}}</ref>
AfriForum CEO Kallie Kriel attracted widespread controversy in May 2018 when he denied that [[Apartheid]] was a [[Crime of apartheid|crime against humanity]],<ref name="mgMay2018KrielApartheidCrime">{{cite web|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2018-05-14-i-dont-think-apartheid-was-a-crime-against-humanity-afriforums-kallie-kriel|title=I don't think apartheid was a crime against humanity – Afriforum’s Kriel|first=Mashadi|last=Kekana|publisher=Mail and Guardian}}</ref><ref name="citizenKrielApartheidCrime">{{cite web|url=https://citizen.co.za/news/news-cns/1926171/apartheid-was-not-a-crime-afriforum/|title=Apartheid was not a crime – AfriForum|first=Robinson|last=Nqola|publisher=The Citizen}}</ref><ref name="702ApartheidCrimeKriel">{{cite web|url=http://www.702.co.za/articles/303461/i-dont-think-apartheid-was-a-crime-against-humanity-kriel|title=AfriForum's Kallie Kriel: I don't think apartheid was a crime against humanity|website=702}}</ref><ref name="news24ApartheidCrimeKriel">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/apartheid-was-not-a-crime-against-humanity-afriforum-ceo-20180514|title=Apartheid was not a crime against humanity - AfriForum CEO|publisher=News24}}</ref><ref name="iolKrielCrimeHumanity">{{cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/apartheid-no-crime-against-humanity-says-afriforums-kriel-14973712|title=Apartheid no crime against humanity, says AfriForum's Kriel|publisher=IOL News}}</ref><ref name ="timesLiveUproarApartheid">{{cite web|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2018-05-15-uproar-over-remark-that-apartheid-was-not-a-crime-against-humanity-by-afriforum-ceo/|title='Apartheid was not a crime against humanity': AfriForum CEO's remark sparks outrage|publisher=Times Live}}</ref><ref name="timesLiveWhoIsKriel">{{cite web|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2018-05-15-who-is-afriforum-ceo-kallie-kriel/|title=Who is AfriForum CEO Kallie Kriel?|publisher=Times Live}}</ref><ref name="iolKrielTryingToRevise">{{cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/pretoria-news/kriel-trying-to-revise-history-14998001|title='Kriel trying to revise history'|publisher=Pretoria News}}</ref> and its deputy leader Ernst Roets has described Apartheid as a "wooly concept".<ref name="huffPoParallelState"/> The organisation had previously described Apartheid as a "so-called historical injustice".<ref name="huffPoFerialMorake">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/ferial-haffajee/ferial-haffajee-tumi-morake-solidarity-and-21st-century-baasskap_a_23216514/|title=Ferial Haffajee: Tumi Morake, Solidarity And 21st Century Baasskap|date=20 September 2017|publisher=Huffington Post}}</ref><ref name="news24DuPreez2016Hijacking"/><ref name="sowetanApartheidCrimeHumanity"/><ref name="businessDayApartheidCrime">{{cite web|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/national/2018-05-15-apartheid-not-a-crime-against-humanity--says-afriforum-ceo-kallie-kriel/|title=Apartheid not a crime against humanity, says AfriForum CEO Kallie Kriel|publisher=Business Day}}</ref>
==Criticism== The organisation has been criticized, most notability by the ruling ANC as well as by media outlets such as City Press, including the paper’s editor Ferial Haffajee<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citypress.co.za/Columnists/Laager-mentality-is-a-load-of-bull-20101002/ |title=Laager mentality is a load of bull |work=News24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121119232400/http://www.citypress.co.za/Columnists/Laager-mentality-is-a-load-of-bull-20101002 |archivedate=2012-11-19 }}</ref> and academics such as University of Cape Town Professor Pierre de Vos.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://constitutionallyspeaking.co.za/how-not-to-engage-in-a-battle-of-ideas/|title=How not to engage in a battle of ideas|work=constitutionallyspeaking.co.za}}</ref> Survivalist groups such as the Kommandokorps have also criticised the organisation, alleging that the group is too moderate in their approach to problems facing South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Kommandokorps-denies-racism-20120227|title=Kommandokorps denies racism|work=News24}}</ref>
A [[Chapter 9 institution]], the [[Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities]], launched an attack on AfriForum's campaign for the protection of [[Afrikaans]] medium schools in a press release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.info.gov.za/speech/DynamicAction?pageid=461&sid=24488&tid=53893 |title=Redirecting old link |work=info.gov.za }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It was presumed by AfriForum that the Commission deliberately acted in contravention of its mandate as set out in Section 185 of the Constitution, which led AfriForum to suspect that the Commission was functioning as an extension of the ruling party.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
The [[African National Congress Youth League]] has stated that AfriForum is "the defender of white privilege"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/afriforum-defender-of-white-priviledge-ancyl-1.1313072|title=Afriforum ‘defender of white privilege’: ANCYL|author=Independent Newspapers Online|work=Independent Online}}</ref> while commentator and journalist [[Max du Preez]] has described AfriForum's position as "reactionary identity politics", and claimed that Afrikaners who criticised AfriForum are "aggressively demonised, insulted, belittled and even threatened".<ref name="duPreezAfriForumDaProblem">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/Columnists/MaxduPreez/the-problem-afriforum-is-causing-the-da-20180515|title=The problem AfriForum is causing the DA|publisher=News24}}</ref>
Vice Chancellor of the [[University of the Witwatersrand]] [[Adam Habib]] condemned AfriForum in May 2018 and said in an interview that the AfriForum was building ties with "[[proto-fascist]] groups" including the French [[National Front (France)|National Front]], the Italian [[Five Star Movement]], and Germany's [[Alternative for Germany|AFD]].<ref name="iolKrielTryingToRevise"/>

'''Biological motion perception''' is the act of perceiving the fluid unique motion of a biological agent. The phenomenon was first documented by Swedish perceptual psychologist, Gunnar Johansson, in 1973.<ref name=Johansson1973>{{cite journal |title=Visual perception of biological motion and a model for its analysis|author=Johansson|journal=Perception & Psychophysics|year=1973|volume=14|pages=201–214|doi=10.3758/bf03212378}}</ref> There are many [[brain]] areas involved in this process, some similar to those used to perceive [[face]]s. While humans complete this process with ease, from a [[computational neuroscience]] perspective there is still much to be learned as to how this complex perceptual problem is solved. One tool which many research studies in this area use is a display [[Stimulus (physiology)|stimuli]] called a point light walker. Point light walkers are coordinated moving dots that simulate biological motion in which each dot represents specific joints of a human performing an action.
Currently a large topic of research, many different models of biological motion/perception have been proposed. The following models have shown that both [[Visual appearance|form]] and [[motion (physics)|motion]] are important components of biological motion perception. However, to what extent each of the components play is contrasted upon the models.
==Neuroanatomy==
Research in this area seeks to identify the specific brain regions or circuits responsible for processing the information which the [[visual system]] perceives in the world. And in this case, specifically recognizing motion created by biological agents.
===Single Cell Recording===
The most precise research is done using [[single-unit recording|single-cell recordings]] in the primate brain. This research has yielded areas important to motion perception in primates such as area MT (middle [[temporal lobe|temporal]] [[visual cortex|visual]] area), also referred to as V5, and area MST ([[medial superior temporal area]]). These areas contain cells characterized as direction cells, expansion/contraction cells, and rotation cells, which react to certain classes of movement.<ref name="Born R., Bradley D." >{{cite journal |title=Structure and Function of Visual Area MT|author=Born, Bradley|journal=Annual Review of Neuroscience|year=2005|volume=28|pages=157–189|doi=10.1146/annurev.neuro.26.041002.131052|pmid=16022593}}</ref><ref name="Tanaka and Saito" >{{cite journal |title=Analysis of Motion of the Visual Field by Direction, Expansion/Contraction, and Rotation Cells Clustered in the Dorsal Part of the Medial Superior Temporal Area of the Macaque Monkey |authors=Tanaka and Saito|journal=Journal of Neurophysiology|year=1989|volume=62|pages=626–641}}</ref><ref name="van Essen and Gallant">{{cite journal |title=Neural Mechanisms of Form and Motion Processing in the Primate Visual System|author=van Essen and Gallant|journal=Neuron|year=1994|volume=13|pages=1–10|doi=10.1016/0896-6273(94)90455-3}}</ref>
===Neuroimaging===
Additionally, research on human participants is being conducted as well. While single-cell recording is not conducted on humans, this research uses [[neuroimaging]] methods such as [[functional magnetic resonance imaging|fMRI]], [[positron emission tomography|PET]], [[electroencephalography|EEG]]/[[event-related potential|ERP]] to collect information on what brain areas become active when executing biological motion perception tasks, such as viewing point light walker stimuli. Areas uncovered from this type of research are the dorsal visual pathway, [[extrastriate body area]], [[fusiform gyrus]], [[superior temporal sulcus]], and [[premotor cortex]]. The [[two-streams hypothesis|dorsal visual pathway]] (sometimes referred to as the “where” pathway), as contrasted with the [[two-streams hypothesis|ventral visual pathway]] (“what” pathway), has been shown to play a significant role in the perception of motion cues. While the ventral pathway is more responsible for form cues.<ref name="Grossman et al">{{cite journal |title=Brain Areas Involved in the Perception of Biological Motion|author=Grossman|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|year=2000|volume=12|pages=711–720|doi=10.1162/089892900562417|pmid=11054914|issue=5|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="Ptito et al">{{cite journal |title=Separate neural pathways for contour and biological-motion cues in motion-defined animal shapes|author=Ptito|journal=NeuroImage|year=2003|volume=19|pages=246–252|doi=10.1016/s1053-8119(03)00082-x|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="Downing et al">{{cite journal |title=A Cortical Area Selective for Visual Processing of the Human Body|author=Downing|journal=Science|year=2001|volume=293|pages=2470–2473|doi=10.1126/science.1063414|pmid=11577239|issue=5539|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="Hadjikhani and Gelder">{{cite journal |title=Seeing Fearful Body Expressions activates the Fusiform Cortex and Amygdala|authors=Hadjikhani and Gelder|journal=Current Biology|year=2003|volume=13|pages=2201–2205|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2003.11.049|pmid=14680638|issue=24}}</ref><ref name=Saygin>{{cite book |last1=Saygin |first1=A.P. |editor-last=Johnson & Shiffrar |editor-first=K. |title=Biological motion perception and the brain: Neuropsychological and neuroimaging studies|publisher=Oxford Series in Visual Cognition |year=2012 |pages=371–389 |chapter=Chapter 21: Sensory and motor brain areas supporting biological motion perception: neuropsychological and neuroimaging studies|lastauthoramp=y}}</ref><ref name="Saygin et al">{{cite journal |title=Point-Light Biological Motion Perception Activates Human Premotor Cortex|author=Saygin|journal=The Journal of Neuroscience|year=2004|volume=24|pages=6181–6188|doi=10.1523/jneurosci.0504-04.2004|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
===Neuropsychological Damage===
Valuable information can also be learned from cases where a patient has suffered from some sort of [[neurology|neurological]] damage and consequently loses certain functionalities of neural processing. One patient with bilateral [[lesion]]s that included the human homologue of area MT, lost their ability to see biological motion when the stimulus was embedded in noise, a task which the average observer is able to complete. Another study on [[stroke]] patients sustaining lesions to their superior temporal and premotor [[frontal lobe|frontal]] areas showed deficits in their processing of biological motion stimuli, thereby implicating these areas as important to that perception process. A [[case study]] conducted on a patient with bilateral lesions involving the posterior [[visual cortex|visual pathways]] and effecting the lateral [[parietal-temporal-occipital]] cortex struggled with early motion tasks, and yet was able to perceive the biological motion of a point light walker, a higher-order task. This may be due to the fact that area V3B and area KO were still intact, suggesting their possible roles in biological motion perception.<ref name="Vaina et al">{{cite journal |title=Intact "biological motion" and "structure from motion" perception in a patient with impaired motion mechanisms|author=Vaina|journal=Visual Neuroscience|year=1990|volume=5|pages=353–369|doi=10.1017/s0952523800000444|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name=Saygin2>{{cite journal |title=Superior temporal and premotor brain areas necessary for biological motion perception|author=Saygin|journal=Brain|year=2007|volume=130|pages=2452–2461|doi=10.1093/brain/awm162|pmid=17660183|issue=Pt 9}}</ref><ref name="Vaina and Giese">{{cite journal |title=Biological motion: Why some motion impaired stroke patients "can" while others "can’t" recognize it? A computational explanation|authors=Vaina & Giese|journal=Journal of Vision|year=2002|volume=2|pages=332|doi=10.1167/2.7.332}}</ref>
==Biological Motion Perception Models==
===Cognitive Model of Biological Motion Form (Lange & Lappe, 2006)<ref name="Lange and Lappe">{{cite journal |title=A Model of Biological Motion Perception from Configural Form Cues |authors=Lange and Lappe|journal=The Journal of Neuroscience|year=2006|volume=26|pages=2894–2906|doi=10.1523/jneurosci.4915-05.2006|pmid=16540566}}</ref>===
====Background==== The relative roles of form cues compared to motion cues in the process of perceiving biological motion is unclear. Previous research has not untangled the circumstances under which local motion cues are needed or only additive. This model looks at how form-only cues can replicate psychophysical results of biological motion perception.
====Model==== ''Template Creation''
Same as below. See 2.2.2 Template Generation
''Stage 1''
The first stage compares stimulus images to the assumed library of upright human walker templates in memory. Each dot in a given stimulus frame is compared to the nearest limb location on a template and these combined, weighted distances are outputted by the function:
::<math>F_{tc}(t) = \sum_{i=1}^n e^ \left (\frac{(\mu_{tc}-p_i(t))^2}{2X\sigma}\right)</math>
where <math> p_i</math> gives the position of a particular stimulus dot and <math> \mu_{tc}</math> represents the nearest limb position in the template. <math>\sigma</math> represents the size of the receptor field to adjust for the size of the stimulus figure.
The best fitting template was then selected by a [[winner-take-all in action selection|winner-takes-all]] mechanism and entered into a [[leaky integrator]]:
::<math>\tau \frac{\delta u_{1,2}(t)}{\delta t} = -u_{1,2}+i_{1,2}+w_+f(u_{1,2}(t))- w_-f(u_{2,1}(t)) </math>
where <math>w_+</math> and <math>w_-</math> are the weights for lateral excitation and inhibition, respectively, and the activities <math>u_{1,2}</math> provide the left/right decision for which direction the stimulus is facing.
''Stage 2''
The second stage attempts to use the [[temporality|temporal]] order of the stimulus frames to change the expectations of what frame would be coming next. The equation
::<math>\tau \frac{\delta v_{1,2}(t)}{\delta t} = -v_{1,2}(t) + w_{m,n}u(t) </math>
takes into account [[top-down and bottom-up design|bottom-up]] input from stage 1 <math>(u)</math>, the activities in decision stage 2 for the possible responses <math>(v_{1,2})</math>, and weights the difference between selected frame <math>n</math> and previous frame <math>m</math>.
''Implications''
This model highlights the abilities of form-related cues to detect biological motion and orientation in a neurologically feasible model. The results of the Stage 1 model showed that all behavioral data could be replicated by using form information alone - global motion information was not necessary to detect figures and their orientation. This model shows the possibility of the use of form cues, but can be criticized for a lack of [[ecological validity]]. Humans do not detect biological figures in static environments and motion is an inherent aspect in upright figure recognition.
===Action Recognition by Motion Detection in Posture Space (Theusner, Lussanet, and Lappe, 2014)===
====Overview==== Old models of [[biological motion]] [[Motion perception|perception]] are concerned with [[Optical motion tracking|tracking]] joint and limb motion relative to one another over time.<ref name="Johansson1973"/> However, recent experiments in biological motion perception have suggested that motion information is unimportant for action recognition.<ref name=Beintema&Lappe2002>{{cite journal |title=Perception of biological motion without local image motion|authors=Beintema and Lappe|journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci USA|year=2002|volume=99|pages=5661–5663|doi=10.1073/pnas.082483699|pmc=122827}}</ref> This model shows how biological motion may be perceived from sequences of [[Posture (psychology)|posture]] recognition, rather than from the direct perception of motion information. An experiment was conducted to test the validity of this model, in which subjects are presented moving point-light and stick-figure walking [[Stimulus (psychology)|stimuli]]. Each frame of the walking stimulus is matched to a posture template, the progression of which is recorded on a 2D posture–time [[Plot (graphics)|plot]] that implies motion recognition.
====Posture Model==== ''Template Generation''
Posture templates for stimulus matching were constructed with motion tracking data from nine people walking.<ref name=Beintema2006>{{cite journal |title=Perception of biological motion from limited lifetime stimuli |vauthors=Beintema JA, Georg K, Lappe M |journal=Percept Psychophys |year=2006 |volume=68 |pages=613–624 |doi=10.3758/bf03208763}}</ref> [[Cartesian coordinate system|3D coordinates]] of the twelve major joints (feet, knees, hips, hands, elbows, and shoulders) were tracked and [[Interpolation|interpolated]] between to generate limb motion. Five sets of 2D projections were created: leftward, frontward, rightward, and the two 45° intermediate orientations. Finally, projections of the nine walkers were [[Normalization (statistics)|normalized]] for walking speed (1.39 seconds at 100 frames per cycle), height, and hip location in posture space. One of the nine walkers was chosen as the walking stimulus, and the remaining eight were kept as templates for matching.
''Template Matching''
Template matching is computed by simulating posture selective [[Artificial neuron|neurons]] as described by <ref name=Lange&Lappe2006>{{cite journal |title=A model of biological motion perception from configural form cues |vauthors=Lange J, Lappe M |journal=J Neurosci |year=2006 |volume=26 |pages=2894–2906 |doi=10.1523/jneurosci.4915-05.2006 |pmid=16540566}}</ref> A neuron is excited by similarity to a static frame of the walker stimulus. For this experiment, 4,000 neurons were generated (8 walkers times 100 frames per cycle times 5 2D projections). A neuron's similarity to a frame of the stimulus is calculated as follows:
::<math>R_\psi(t) = \sum_{i = 1}^N \exp \left( - \frac{\left | (x_i(t), y_i(t)) - (\Chi_i, _\psi, \Rho_i, _\psi) \right \vert ^2}{2 \sdot \sigma} \right)</math>
where <math>(x_i, y_i)</math> describe a stimulus point and <math>(c_i, r_i)</math> describe the limb location at time <math>t</math>; <math>\psi</math> describes the preferred posture; <math>R</math> describes a neuron's response to a stimulus of <math>N</math> points; and <math>\sigma</math> describes limb width.
''Response Simulation''
The neuron most closely resembling the posture of the walking stimulus changes over time. The neural activation pattern can be graphed in a 2D plot, called a posture-time plot. Along the x axis, templates are sorted chronologically according to a forward walking pattern. Time progresses along the y axis with the beginning corresponding to the origin. The perception of forward walking motion is represented as a line with a positive [[slope]] from the origin, while backward walking is conversely represented as a line with a negative slope.
====Motion Model==== ''Motion Detection in Posture Space''
The posture-time plots used in this model follow the established space-time plots used for describing object motion.<ref name=Adelson&Bergen1985>{{cite journal |title=Spatiotemporal energy models for the perception of motion |vauthors=Adelson EH, Bergen JR |journal=J Opt Soc Am |year=1985 |volume=2 |pages=284–299 |doi=10.1364/josaa.2.000284 |pmid=3973762}}</ref> Space-time plots with time at the y axis and the spatial dimension at the x axis, define [[velocity]] of an object by the slope of the line. Information about an object's motion can be detected by spatio-temporal [[Filter (higher-order function)|filters]].<ref name=Rechardt1957>{{cite journal |title=Autokorrelations-Auswertung als Funktionsprinzip des Zentralnervensystems |author=Reichardt W |journal=Z Naturforsch |year=1957 |volume=12 |pages=448–457}}</ref><ref name=vanSanten&Sperling1984>{{cite journal |title=Temporal covariance model of human motion perception |vauthors=van Santen JP, Sperling G |journal=J Opt Soc Am |year=1984 |volume=1 |pages=451–473 |doi=10.1364/josaa.1.000451}}</ref> In this biological motion model, motion is detected similarly but replaces the spatial dimension for posture space along the x axis, and body motion is detected by using posturo-temporal filters rather than spatio-temporal filters.
''Posturo-Temporal Filters''
Neural responses are first normalized as described by <ref name=Simoncelli&Heeger1998>{{cite journal |title=A model of neuronal responses in visual area MT |vauthors=Simoncelli EP, Heeger DJ |journal=Vision Res |year=1998 |volume=38 |pages=743–761 |doi=10.1016/s0042-6989(97)00183-1}}</ref>
::<math>\nu_\psi(t) = \frac{R_\psi(t) - \bar{R}}{\bar{R}}</math>
where <math>R_y(t)</math> describes the neural response; <math>_\psi</math> describes the preferred posture at time <math>t</math>; <math>\bar{R}</math> describes the mean neural response over all neurons over <math>t</math>; and <math>n_y(t)</math> describes the normalized response. The filters are defined for forward and backward walking (<math>g^f, g^b</math> respectively). The response of the posturo-temporal filter is described
::<math>r_\psi(\tau) = \sum_{t=0ms}^\tau \sum_{p=1}^{100} g_{\tau, \psi} (t, p) \sdot \nu_\psi(t)</math>
where <math>r</math> is the response of the filter at time <math>\tau</math>; and <math>p</math> describes the posture dimension. The response of the filter is normalized by
::<math>N_\psi(\tau) = \max \left [ \left ( \frac{r_\psi(\tau)}{\sum_t \sum_p g_{\tau, \psi} (t, p)^2} \right ), 0 \right ]</math>
where <math>N</math> describes the response of the neuron selecting body motion. Finally, body motion is calculated by
::<math>\varepsilon_\psi(\tau) = N_\psi^F(\tau)^2 - N_\psi^B(\tau)^2</math>
where <math>\varepsilon</math> describes body motion energy.
===Critical Features for the Recognition of Biological Motion (Casille and Giese, 2005)===
====Statistical Analysis and Psychophysical Experiments==== The following model suggests that biological motion recognition could be accomplished through the extraction of a single critical feature: dominant local [[Optical flow|optic flow]] motion. These following assumptions were brought about from results of both statistical analysis and [[Psychophysics|psychophysical]] experiments.<ref name=Casile2005>{{cite journal |title=Critical features for the recognition of biological motion|authors=Casile, & Giese |journal=Journal of Vision |year=2005 |volume=5 |pages=348–360 |doi=10.1167/5.4.6}}</ref>
First, [[Principal component analysis]] was done on full body [[2d computer graphics|2d]] walkers and point light walkers. The analysis found that dominant local optic flow features are very similar in both full body 2d stimuli and point light walkers (Figure 1).<ref name="Casile2005"/> Since subjects can recognize biological motion upon viewing a point light walker, then the similarities between these two stimuli may highlight critical features needed for biological motion recognition.
Through psychophysical experiments, it was found that [[Human subject research|subjects]] could recognize biological motion using a CFS [[Stimulus (physiology)|stimulus]] which contained opponent motion in the horizontal direction but randomly moving dots in the horizontal direction (Figure 2).<ref name="Casile2005"/> Because of the movement of the dots, this stimulus could not be fit to a human [[skeleton]] model suggesting that biological motion recognition may not heavily rely on form as a critical feature. Also, the psychophysical experiments showed that subjects similarly recognize biological motion for both the CFS stimulus and SPS, a stimulus in which dots of the point light walker were reassigned to different positions within the human body shape for every nth frame thereby highlights the importance of form vs the motion (Fig.1.).<ref name=Beintema2002>{{cite journal |title=Perception of biological motion without local image motion|authors=Beintema, & Lappe |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |year=2002 |volume=99|issue =8|pages=5661–5663 |doi=10.1073/pnas.082483699|pmc=122827}}</ref> The results of the following psychophysical experiments show that motion is a critical feature that could be used to recognize biological motion.
The following statistical analysis and psychophysical experiments highlight the importance of dominant local motion patterns in biological motion recognition.Furthermore, due to the ability of subjects to recognize biological motion given the CFS stimulus, it is postulated that [[Horizontal plane|horizontal]] opponent motion and coarse positional information is important for recognition of biological motion.
====Model==== The following model contains detectors modeled from existing neurons that extracts motion features with increasing complexity. (Figure 4).<ref name="Casile2005"/>
''Detectors of Local Motion''
These detectors detect different motion directions and are modeled from neurons in monkey V1/2 and area [[Middle temporal gyrus|MT]]<ref name=Snowden1994>{{cite journal |title=Motion processing in the primate cerebral cortex|author=Snowden, R.J. |journal=Visual detection of motion |year=1994 |pages=51–84}}</ref> The output of the local motion detectors are the following: ::<math>G_p(x) = H(v(x),v_1,v_2) \cdot b(\theta,\theta_p) </math>
where <math>x</math> is the position with preferred direction <math>\theta_p,</math>, <math>v</math> is the velocity, <math>\theta</math> is the direction, and <math>H</math> is the rectangular speed tuning function such that
::<math>H(v,v_1,v_2) = 1 </math> for <math> v_1 < v < v_2 </math> and <math> H(v,v_1,v_2) = 0 </math> otherwise.
The direction-tuning of motion energy detectors are given by
::<math> b(\theta,\theta_p)=\left\{ \left ( \frac{1}{2} \right ) \left [\ 1 + cos(\theta,\theta_p)\right]\ \right\}^q </math>
where <math>q</math> is a parameter that determines width of direction tuning function. (q=2 for simulation).
''Neural detectors for opponent motion selection''
The following neural detectors are used to detect horizontal and vertical opponent motion due by pooling together the output of previous local motion energy detectors into two adjacent subfields. Local motion detectors that have the same direction preference are combined into the same subfield. These detectors were modeled after neurons sensitive to opponent motion such as the ones in [[Middle temporal gyrus|MT]] and [[Superior temporal sulcus|medial superior temporal (MST)]].<ref name=Born2000>{{cite journal |title=Center-surround interactions in the middle temporal visual area of the owl monkey|author=Born, R.T. |journal=Journal of Neurophysiology |year=2000 |volume = 84|pages=2658–2669}}</ref><ref name=Tanaka1989>{{cite journal |title=Analysis of motion in the visual field by direction, expansion/contraction, and rotation cells clustered in the dorsal part of the medial superior temporal area of the macaque monkey|author1=Tanaka, K. |author2=Saito, H |lastauthoramp=yes |journal=Journal of Neurophysiology |year=2000 |volume = 62| issue = 3| pages=535–552}}</ref> Also, KO/V3B has been associated with processing edges, moving objects, and opponent motion. Patients with damage to dorsal pathway areas but an intact KO/V3B, as seen in patient AF can still perceive biological motion.<ref name=Vaina1990>{{cite journal |title=Intact "biological motion" and "structure from motion" perception in a patient with impaired motion mechanisms: A case study |authors=Vaina, L. M., Lemay, M., Bienfang, D., Choi, A. & Nakayama, K. |journal=Visual Neuroscience |year=1990 |volume = 5| pages=353–369 |doi=10.1017/s0952523800000444}}</ref>
The output for these detectors are the following:
::<math>o_l(x)=\sqrt{max(g_p(x_i))max(g_r(x_j))}</math>
where <math> x </math> is the position the output is centered at, direction preferences <math> p </math> and <math> r </math>, and <math>i,j</math> signify spatial positions of two subfields.
The final output of opponent motion detector is given as
::<math>o_l(x)=max(o_l(x_k))</math>
where output is the pooled responses of detectors of type <math> l </math> at <math> x_k </math> different spatial positions.
''Detectors of optic flow patterns''
Each detector looks at one frame of a training stimulus and compute an instantaneous optic flow field for that particular frame. These detectors model neurons in [[Superior temporal sulcus]]<ref name=Grossman2000>{{cite journal |title=Brain areas involved in perception of biological motion|authors=Grossman, E. Donnelly, M. Price, R., Pickens, D. Morgan, V., Neighbor, G. |journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience |year=2000 |volume = 12|issue = 5| pages=711–720 |doi=10.1162/089892900562417 |pmid=11054914|display-authors=etal}}</ref> and [[Fusiform face area]]<ref name=Grossman2002>{{cite journal |title=Brain areas active during visual perception of biological motion|author1=Grossman, E. |author2=Blake, R. |lastauthoramp=yes |journal=Neuron |year=2002 |volume = 35|pages=1167–1175 |doi=10.1016/s0896-6273(02)00897-8 |pmid=12354405}}</ref>
The input of these detectors is arranged from vector u and are comprised from the previous opponent motion detectors’ responses. The output is the following:
::<math>G(u) = e^{(u-u_0)^T C(u-u_0)}</math>
such that <math>u_0</math> is the center of the [[radial basis function]] for each neuron and <math> C </math> is a diagonal matrix which contains elements that have been set during training and correspond to vector u. These elements equal zero if the variance over training doesn't exceed a certain threshold. Otherwise, these elements equal the inverse of variance.
Since recognition of biological motion is dependent on the sequence of activity, the following model is sequence selective. The activity of the optic flow pattern neuron is modeled by the following equation of
::<math>\tau H_k^l(t) = -H_k^l(t) + \sum_m w(k-m)f(H_k^l(t)+G_k^l(t))</math>
in which <math>k</math> is a specific frame in the <math>l</math>-th training sequence, <math>\tau</math> is the time constant.<math>f(H)</math> a threshold function, <math>w(m)</math> is an asymmetric interaction kernel, and <math>G_k^l(t)</math> is obtained from the previous section.
''Detectors of complete biological motion patterns'' The following detectors sum the output of the optic flow pattern detectors in order to selectively activate for whole movement patterns (e.g. walking right vs. walking left). These detectors model similar neurons that optic flow pattern detectors model:
[[Superior temporal sulcus]]<ref name="Grossman2000"/> and [[Fusiform face area]]<ref name="Grossman2002"/>
The input of these detectors are the activity of the optic flow motion detectors, <math>H_l^l(t)</math>. The output of these detectors are the following:
::<math>\tau_s P^l (t) = -P^l(t) + \sum_k H_l^l(t)</math>
such that <math>P^l(t)</math> is the activity of the complete biological motion pattern detector in response to pattern type <math> l </math> (e.g. walking to the left), <math> \tau_s </math> equals the time constant (used 150 ms in simulation), and <math>H_k^l(t)</math> equals the activity of optic flow pattern detector at kth frame in sequence l.
====Testing the model====
Using correct determination of walking direction of both the CFS and SPS stimulus, the model was able to replicate similar results as the psychophysical experiments. (could determine walking direction of CFS and SPS stimuli and increasing correct with increasing number of dots). It is postulated that recognition of biological motion is made possible by the opponent horizontal motion information that is present in both the CFS and SPS stimuli.

{{one source|date=December 2010}} {{main|Prospect theory}} The '''certainty effect''' is the psychological effect resulting from the reduction of probability from certainty to probable {{harv|Tversky|Kahneman|1986}}. It is an idea introduced in [[prospect theory]].
Normally a reduction in the probability of winning a reward (e.g., a reduction from 80% to 20% in the chance of winning a reward) creates a psychological effect such as displeasure to individuals, which leads to the perception of loss from the original probability thus favoring a risk-averse decision. However, the same reduction results in a larger psychological effect when it is done from certainty than from uncertainty.
==Example== {{harvtxt|Tversky|Kahneman|1986}} illustrated the certainty effect by the following examples.
First, consider this example:
Which of the following options do you prefer? *A. a sure gain of $30 *B. 80% chance to win $45 and 20% chance to win nothing
In this case, 78% of participants chose option A while only 22% chose option B. This demonstrates the typical risk-aversion phenomenon in [[prospect theory]] and [[framing effect]] because the expected value of option B ($45x0.8=$36) exceeds that of A by 20%.
Now, consider this problem:
Which of the following options do you prefer?
*C. 25% chance to win $30 and 75% chance to win nothing *D. 20% chance to win $45 and 80% chance to win nothing
In this case, 42% of participants chose option C while 58% chose option D.
As before, the expected value of the first option ($30x0.25=$7.50) was 20% lower than that of option D ($45x0.2=9) however, when neither option was certain, risk-taking increased.
==See also== * [[Pseudocertainty effect]] * [[Framing effect (psychology)|Framing effect]] * [[Prospect theory]] * [[Allais paradox]]

{{Orphan|date=January 2014}}
[[File:Hugh Laurie Actors Guild.jpg|thumb|upright|In the medical drama, ''[[House (TV series)|House]]'', actor [[Hugh Laurie]] played a brilliant but obnoxious ''[[prima donna]]'' who would today be characterised as a disruptive physician.<ref>{{citation | url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/opinion/forum/story/2012-05-21/house-md-doctors-disruptive-behavior/55118270/1 | title=Gregory House M.D.: RIP | publisher=[[USA Today]] | date=May 22, 2012 | author=[[Robert M. Wachter]]}}</ref>]] A '''disruptive physician''' is a [[physician]] whose obnoxious behaviour upsets patients or other staff. The [[American Medical Association]] defines this in their code of [[medical ethics]] as "personal conduct, whether verbal or physical, that negatively affects or that potentially may affect patient care".<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ar9Wn_aeCwQC&pg=PA133 |pages=131–152 |title=Professionalism in Psychiatry |chapter=The Disruptive Physician |publisher=American Psychiatric Pub. |year=2011 |isbn=9781585623372}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.ama-assn.org/ama/pub/physician-resources/medical-ethics/code-medical-ethics/opinion9045.page |title=AMA Code of Medical Ethics |chapter=Physicians with Disruptive Behavior |year=2000 |publisher=[[American Medical Association]]}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.ama-assn.org/resources/doc/code-medical-ethics/9045a.pdf |title=Physicians With Disruptive Behavior |author=Herbert Rakatansky |publisher=[[American Medical Association]] |year=2000}}</ref> These behaviors are also noted as causing adverse effects such as morale, focus and concentration, team work, collaboration and communication. Starting in 2009, The [[Joint Commission]] which [[accreditation|accredits]] hospitals in the United States requires them to have a written [[code of conduct]] addressing this issue.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/02/health/02rage.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |title=Arrogant, Abusive and Disruptive — and a Doctor |author=Laurie Tarkan |date=December 1, 2008 |journal=[[New York Times]]}}</ref> This code of conduct defines acceptable, disruptive, and unacceptable behavior in the workplace. Along with these definitions of behaviors the Joint Commission also wrote ways to manage these behaviors in order to fix them.
[[Simon Sebag Montefiore]] has reported a remarkable tendency for doctors to become tyrannical dictators.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/london-life/the-doctators-why-are-so-many-tyrants-medically-qualified-8841221.html |journal=Evening Standard |title=The doctators: why are so many tyrants medically qualified? |author=[[Simon Sebag Montefiore]] |date=26 Sep 2013}}</ref> Historical examples include:
* [[Bashar al-Assad]] * [[Hastings Banda]] * [[François Duvalier|François "Papa Doc" Duvalier]] * [[Félix Houphouët-Boigny]] * [[Radovan Karadžić]] * [[William Walker (filibuster)|William Walker]]
==See also== *[[Bullying in medicine]] *[[Doc Martin]] *[[Medical drama]] *[[Medical malpractice]] *[[The No Asshole Rule]]
==References== {{reflist}} Jacob DeLaRosa. The Disruptive Physician, ''How to Manage the Consequences of Being You'' Misner & Monroe, New York 2017
==Further reading== *{{citation |author=Daniel Lang|title=The Disabled Physician: Problem Solving Strategies for the Medical Staff |url=http://www.csam-asam.org/sites/default/files/pdf/misc/Lang_book_OCR_version.pdf |year=1989 |publisher=American Hospital Publishing |pages=17–21 |chapter=The Disruptive Physician, The Sociopathic Physician}} *{{citation |vauthors=Benzer DG, Miller MM |title=The Disruptive – Abusive Physician: A New Look at an Old Problem |journal=Wisconsin Medical Journal |year=1995 |number=94 |pages=455–459}} *{{citation |author=Pfifferling J-H |title=Managing the Unmanageable: The Disruptive Physician |journal=Family Practice Management |year=1997 |issue=Nov/Dec |pages=77–92}}

{{About|the psychological experience||Dissociation (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox symptom | name = Dissociation (psychology) | image = | alt = | caption = | field = [[Psychiatry]] | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|F44}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|300.12}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | MeSH = | GeneReviewsNBK = | GeneReviewsName = }}
In [[psychology]], '''dissociation''' is any of a wide array of experiences from mild [[Emotional detachment|detachment]] from immediate surroundings to more severe detachment from physical and emotional experiences. The major characteristic of all dissociative phenomena involves a detachment from [[reality]], rather than a loss of reality as in [[psychosis]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Dell P. F. |title=A new model of dissociative identity disorder |journal=Psychiatric Clinics North America |volume=29 |issue=1 |pages=1–26, vii |date=March 2006 |pmid=16530584 |doi=10.1016/j.psc.2005.10.013 |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Butler LD, etal |title=Hypnotizability and traumatic experience: a diathesis-stress model of dissociative symptomatology |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=153 |issue=7 Suppl |pages=42–63 |date=July 1996 |pmid=8659641 |doi= 10.1176/ajp.153.7.42|url=http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=8659641}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gleaves |first1= DH |last2= May |first2= MC |last3= Cardeña |first3= E |title=An examination of the diagnostic validity of dissociative identity disorder |journal=Clinical Psychology Review |volume=21 |issue=4 |pages=577–608 |date=June 2001 |pmid=11413868 |doi= 10.1016/S0272-7358(99)00073-2|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0272-7358(99)00073-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Dell P. F. |title=The multidimensional inventory of dissociation (MID): A comprehensive measure of pathological dissociation |journal=Journal of Trauma Dissociation |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=77–106 |year=2006 |pmid=16769667 |doi= 10.1300/J229v07n02_06|url=}}</ref>
Dissociation is commonly displayed on a [[Continuum (measurement)|continuum]].<ref name="Dell2009">{{cite book | authors = Dell, P. F., & O'Neil, J. A. | year = 2009 | chapter = Preface | editors = P.F. Dell & J.A. O'Neil | title = Dissociation and the dissociative disorders: DSM-V and beyond | pages = [https://books.google.com/books?id=e–6WHeIf–dgC&pg=PR19 xix–xxi] | location = New York | publisher = [[Routledge]]}}</ref> In mild cases, dissociation can be regarded as a [[Coping (psychology)|coping mechanism]] or [[defense mechanism]]s in seeking to master, [[Minimisation (psychology)|minimize]] or tolerate [[Stress (biology)|stress]] – including boredom or [[Emotional conflict|conflict]].<ref name="Weiten">{{cite book |last1= Weiten |first1= W. |last2= Lloyd |first2= M.A. | year = 2008 | title = Psychology Applied to Modern Life | edition = 9 | publisher = Wadsworth Cengage Learning | isbn = 0-495-55339-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor = Snyder, C.R. | year = 1999 | title = Coping: The Psychology of What Works| location = New York | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | isbn = 0-19-511934-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last1 = Zeidner |editor-first1= M. |editor-last2= Endler |editor-first2= N.S. | year = 1996 | title = Handbook of Coping: Theory, Research, Applications| location = New York | publisher = [[John Wiley & Sons]] | isbn = 0-471-59946-8 }}</ref> At the nonpathological end of the continuum, dissociation describes common events such as [[daydreaming]]. Further along the continuum are non-pathological [[altered states of consciousness]].<ref name="Dell2009"/><ref>{{cite book | authors = Lynn S & Rhue JW | year = 1994 | title = Dissociation: clinical and theoretical perspectives | publisher = [[Guilford Press]]|isbn=978-0-89862-186-0 | page = 19|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BWLockQL714C&pg=PA19 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | authors = Van der Kolk, B. A., Van der Hart, O., & Marmar, C. R. | year = 1996 | chapter = Dissociation and information processing in posttraumatic stress disorder| editors = B. A. van der Kolk, A. C. McFarlane, & L. Weisaeth| title = Traumatic stress: The effects of overwhelming experience on mind, body, and society | pages = [https://books.google.com/books?id=C9owN3KYOSwC&pg=PA303 303–27]| location = New York | publisher = [[Guilford Press]] }}</ref>
More pathological dissociation involves [[dissociative disorder]]s, including [[dissociative fugue]] and [[depersonalization disorder]] with or without alterations in personal identity or sense of self. These alterations can include: a sense that self or the world is unreal ([[depersonalization]] and [[derealization]]); a loss of memory ([[amnesia]]); forgetting identity or assuming a new self (fugue); and separate streams of consciousness, identity and self ([[dissociative identity disorder]], formerly termed multiple personality disorder) and [[complex post-traumatic stress disorder]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Coons PM |title=Psychogenic or dissociative fugue: a clinical investigation of five cases |journal=Psychological Reports |volume=84 |issue=3 Pt 1 |pages=881–6 |date=June 1999 |pmid=10408212 |doi= 10.2466/PR0.84.3.881-886|url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kritchevsky |first1= M |last2= Chang |first2= J |last3= Squire |first3= LR |title=Functional Amnesia: Clinical Description and Neuropsychological Profile of 10 Cases |journal=Learning and Memory |volume=11|issue= 2 |pages=213–26 |year=2004 |pmid=15054137 |pmc=379692 |doi=10.1101/lm.71404 |url=}}</ref>
Dissociative disorders are sometimes triggered by trauma, but may be preceded only by stress, psychoactive substances, or no identifiable trigger at all.<ref>{{cite book |last1= Abugel |first1= J |last2= Simeon |first2= D |title=Feeling Unreal: Depersonalization Disorder and the Loss of the Self |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |location=Oxford |year=2006 | page= [https://books.google.com/?id=M-Cgs_T7Cl8C&pg=PA17 17] |isbn=0195170229}}</ref> The [[ICD-10]] classifies [[conversion disorder]] as a [[dissociative disorder]].<ref name="Dell2009"/> The [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]] groups all dissociative disorders into a single category.<ref>{{cite book | last = American Psychiatric Association | authorlink = American Psychiatric Association | title = [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-IV (Text Revision)]] | pages = [https://books.google.com/books?id=3SQrtpnHb9MC&pg=PA519 519–34] | date = June 2000 | publisher = American Psychiatric Publishing, Inc. | location = Arlington, VA, USA | isbn = 978-0-89042-024-9 | doi = 10.1176/appi.books.9780890423349 }}</ref>
Although some dissociative disruptions involve amnesia, other dissociative events do not.<ref>{{cite journal | title = The measurement of dissociation in normal and clinical populations: meta-analytic validation of the dissociative experiences scale (DES) | journal = Clinical Psychology Review | last1 = Van IJzendoorn |first1= MH |last2=Schuengel |first2= C | volume = 16 | issue = 5 | pages = 365–382 | doi = 10.1016/0272-7358(96)00006-2 | year = 1996 | url = https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0272735896000062}}</ref> Dissociative disorders are typically experienced as startling, autonomous intrusions into the person's usual ways of responding or functioning. Due to their unexpected and largely inexplicable nature, they tend to be quite unsettling.
== History == [[French people|French]] philosopher and [[psychologist]] [[Pierre Janet]] (1859–1947) is considered to be the author of the concept of dissociation.<ref name = Ellenberger>{{cite book |last=Ellenberger | first = H. F. |title=The Discovery of the Unconscious: The History and Evolution of Dynamic Psychiatry |publisher=BasicBooks |location=New York |year=1970 |pages= |isbn=0-465-01673-1 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> Contrary to some conceptions of dissociation, Janet did not believe that dissociation was a psychological defense.<ref>{{cite book | last = Janet | first = P | authorlink = Pierre Janet |origyear= 1893/1901 |year= 1977 | title = The Mental State of Hystericals: A Study of Mental Stigmata and Mental Accidents | location = Washington, DC | publisher = University Publications of America | url = https://books.google.com/?id=6OctAAAAIAAJ | isbn = 0-89093-166-6 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Janet | first= Pierre | authorlink = Pierre Janet | origyear = 1920/1929 |year= 1965 | title = The major symptoms of hysteria | url = https://books.google.com/?id=yyQ6AAAAMAAJ | location = New York | publisher = Hafner Publishing Company | isbn = 1-4325-0431-2 }}</ref>
Psychological [[defense mechanism]]s belong to Freud's theory of [[psychoanalysis]], not to Janetian psychology. Janet claimed that dissociation occurred only in persons who had a constitutional weakness of mental functioning that led to [[hysteria]] when they were [[Stress (biological)|stressed]]. Although it is true that many of Janet's [[Case study|case histories]] described traumatic experiences, he never considered dissociation to be a defense against those experiences. Quite the opposite: Janet insisted that dissociation was a mental or cognitive deficit. Accordingly, he considered trauma to be one of many stressors that could worsen the already-impaired "mental efficiency" of a hysteric, thereby generating a cascade of hysterical (in today's language, "dissociative") symptoms.<ref name = Ellenberger/><ref>{{cite book | last = McDougall | first = W | year = 1926| title = Outline of abnormal psychology| url = https://books.google.com/?id=86pWAAAAMAAJ | location = New York | publisher = [[Charles Scribner's Sons]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Mitchell | first = TW | year = 1921 | title = The Psychology of Medicine | location = London | publisher = Methuen | isbn = 0-8274-4240-8 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=k1cwAAAACAAJ}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Mitchell | first = TW | origyear = 1923 |year= 2007 | title = Medical Psychology and Psychical Research | location = New York | publisher = [[E. P. Dutton]] | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pxsZIg6_yhMC| isbn = 1-4067-3500-0}}</ref>
Although there was great interest in dissociation during the last two decades of the nineteenth century (especially in France and England), this interest rapidly waned with the coming of the new century.<ref name=Ellenberger/> Even Janet largely turned his attention to other matters.
On the other hand, there was a sharp peak in interest in dissociation in America from 1890 to 1910, especially in Boston as reflected in the work of [[William James]], [[Boris Sidis]], [[Morton Prince]], and [[William McDougall (psychologist)|William McDougall]]. Nevertheless, even in America, interest in dissociation rapidly succumbed to the surging academic interest in psychoanalysis and behaviorism.
For most of the twentieth century, there was little interest in dissociation. Despite this, a review of 76 previously published cases (from 1790’s – 1942),was published in 1944, describing clinical phenomena consistent with that seen by Janet and by therapists today<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Taylor|first=WS|last2=Martin|first2=Mabel F|date=1944|title=Multiple Personality|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/h0063634|journal=The Journal of Abnormal and Social Psychology|volume=39(3)|pages=281-300|via=}}</ref>. In 1971 Bowers and her colleagues<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bowers|first=MK|last2=Brecher-Marer|first2=Sylvia|last3=Newton|first3=Bernauer. W.|last4=Piotrowski|first4=Zygmunt|last5=Spyer|first5=Thea C.|last6=Taylor|first6=William S.|last7=Watkins|first7=John G|date=1971|title=Therapy of Multiple Personality|url=|journal=The International Journal of Clinical and Experimental Hypnosis|volume=14(2)|pages=57-65|via=}}</ref> presented a detailed, and still quite valid, treatment article. The authors of this article included leading thinkers of their time – [[John G. Watkins]] (who developed [[Ego-state therapy]]) and [[Zygmunt A. Piotrowski]] (famed for his work on the [[Rorschach test|Rorschach]] test). Further interest in dissociation was evoked when [[Ernest Hilgard]] (1977) published his neodissociation theory in the 1970s. During the 1970's and 1980's an increasing number of clinicians and researchers wrote about dissociation, particularly multiple personality disorder.<ref>Van der Hart, O & Dorahy, M.J. (2009). History of the concept of Dissociation. In Dell, P.F. & O'Neil J.A. (Eds). ''Dissociation and the Dissociative Disorders: DSM V and beyond,'' Routledge, New York</ref>.
[[Carl Jung]] described pathological manifestations of dissociation as special or extreme cases of the normal operation of the psyche. This structural dissociation, opposing tension, and hierarchy of basic [[attitude (psychology)|attitudes]] and functions in normal individual consciousness is the basis of Jung's ''[[Psychological Types]]''.<ref name=Jung1991>{{cite book |last = Jung |first= C.G. |authorlink= Carl Jung | year = 1991 | title = Psychological Types | publisher = Routledge London | isbn = 978-0-7100-6299-4 }}</ref> He theorized that dissociation is a natural necessity for consciousness to operate in one faculty unhampered by the demands of its opposite.
Attention to dissociation as a clinical feature has been growing in recent years as knowledge of [[post-traumatic stress disorder]] increased, due to interest in [[dissociative identity disorder]], and as [[neuroimaging]] research and population studies show its relevance.<ref>{{cite book | last = Scaer | first = Robert C. | title = The Body Bears the Burden: Trauma, Dissociation, and Disease | publisher = Haworth Medical Press | year = 2001 | location = Binghamton, NY | pages = 97–126 | isbn = 0-7890-1246-4 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=C30EbO7GDMIC&pg=PA97}}</ref>
Historically the psychopathological concept of dissociation has also another different root: the conceptualization of [[Eugen Bleuler]] that looks into dissociation related to schizophrenia.<ref>{{cite journal |editor-first1= M |editor-last1= Di Fiorino |editor-first2= ML |editor-last2= Figueira |title= Dissociation. Dissociative phenomena. Questions and answers |journal= Bridging Eastern & Western Psychiatry |volume= 1 |issue= 1 |pages= 1–134 |year= 2003}}</ref>
== Diagnosis == {{Main|Dissociative disorder}} Dissociation in community samples is most commonly measured by the [[Dissociative Experiences Scale]]. The ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|DSM-IV]]'' considers symptoms such as [[depersonalization]], [[derealization]] and [[psychogenic amnesia]] to be core features of [[dissociative disorder]]s.<ref name="DissociativeDisorders">[[Dissociative disorder|Dissociative Disorders ( Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition )]]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> However, in the normal population, dissociative experiences that are not clinically significant are highly prevalent with 60% to 65% of the respondents indicating that they have had some dissociative experiences.<ref name=OccrRef04102007>{{cite journal |last1= Waller |first1= NG |last2= Putnam |first2= FW |last3= Carlson |first3= EB | year = 1996 | title = Types of dissociation and dissociative types: A taxometric analysis of dissociative experiences | journal = Psychological Methods | volume = 1 |issue= 3 | pages = 300–21 | url = http://www.psych.umn.edu/faculty/waller/classes/mult06/taxometrics/wallerputnam.pdf | accessdate = 2008-01-31 | doi = 10.1037/1082-989X.1.3.300 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080829105150/http://www.psych.umn.edu/faculty/waller/classes/mult06/taxometrics/wallerputnam.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-08-29}}</ref> The [[Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV#SCID-D|SCID-D]] is a structured interview used to assess and diagnose dissociation.
== Relation to trauma and abuse == Dissociation has been described as one of a constellation of symptoms experienced by some victims of multiple forms of childhood [[Psychological trauma|trauma]], including [[physical abuse|physical]], [[psychological abuse|psychological]], and [[child sexual abuse|sexual abuse]].<ref name=salter>{{cite book|title=Transforming Trauma: A Guide to Understanding and Treating Adult Survivors |first=Anna C. |last=Salter |first2=Hilary |last2= Eldridge |page=220 | year=1995 |publisher=Sage Publications |isbn= 0-8039-5509-X}}</ref><ref name=Myers>{{cite book |title=The APSAC Handbook on Child Maltreatment |edition= 2nd |first=John E.B. |last=Myers |page=63 |publisher=Sage Publications |year=2002 |isbn= 0-7619-1992-9}}</ref> This is supported by studies which suggest that dissociation is correlated with a history of trauma.<ref name="pmid8659645">{{cite journal | author = van der Kolk, BA| title = Dissociation, somatization, and affect dysregulation: The complexity of adaptation of trauma | journal = American Journal of Psychiatry | volume = 153 | issue = 7 Suppl | pages = 83–93 | year = 1996 | pmid = 8659645 | doi = 10.1176/ajp.153.7.83 | url = http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=8659645 | accessdate = 2008-05-13|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
Dissociation appears to have a high [[Specificity (tests)|specificity]] and a low [[Sensitivity (tests)|sensitivity]] to having a self-reported history of trauma, which means that dissociation is much more common among those who are traumatized, yet at the same time there are many people who have suffered from trauma but who do not show dissociative symptoms.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Briere |first=J |title=Dissociative symptoms and trauma exposure: Specificity, affect dysregulation, and posttraumatic stress |journal=Journal of Nervous and Mental Disorders |volume=194 |issue=2 |pages=78–82 |year=2006 |pmid=16477184 |doi=10.1097/01.nmd.0000198139.47371.54 |url=http://www.johnbriere.com/JNMD%2006%20paper.html |access-date=2008-05-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820094201/http://www.johnbriere.com/JNMD%2006%20paper.html |archive-date=2008-08-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Adult dissociation when combined with a history of [[child abuse]] and otherwise interpersonal violence-related [[posttraumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD) has been shown to contribute to disturbances in parenting behavior, such as exposure of young children to violent media. Such behavior may contribute to cycles of familial violence and trauma.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Schechter |first1= DS |last2= Gross |first2= A |last3= Willheim |first3= E |last4= McCaw |first4= J |last5= Turner |first5= JB |last6= Myers |first6= MM |last7= Zeanah |first7= CH |last8= Gleason |first8= MM |authorlink1= Daniel Schechter |displayauthors= 4 |title= Is maternal PTSD associated with greater exposure of very young children to violent media? |journal= Journal of Traumatic Stress |year= 2009 |pages= 658–62 |pmid= 19924819 |pmc= 2798921 |doi= 10.1002/jts.20472 |volume=22|issue= 6 }}</ref>
Symptoms of dissociation resulting from trauma may include [[depersonalization]], [[psychological numbing]], [[Apathy|disengagement]], or amnesia regarding the events of the abuse. It has been hypothesized that dissociation may provide a temporarily effective defense mechanism in cases of severe trauma; however, in the long term, dissociation is associated with decreased psychological functioning and adjustment.<ref name=Myers/>
Other symptoms sometimes found along with dissociation in victims of traumatic abuse (often referred to as "sequelae to abuse") include anxiety, PTSD, low [[self-esteem]], somatization, depression, chronic pain, interpersonal dysfunction, substance abuse, self-harm and suicidal ideation or actions.<ref name=salter/><ref name=Myers/><ref name=briere1992>{{cite journal |url=http://www.johnbriere.com/methodological%20csa%20jccp%201992.pdf |title=Methodological issues in the study of sexual abuse effects |last=Briere |first=J |journal=Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology |year=1992 |pages=196–203 |volume=60 |pmid=1592948 |doi=10.1037/0022-006X.60.2.196 |issue=2 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080911152635/http://www.johnbriere.com/methodological%20csa%20jccp%201992.pdf |archivedate=2008-09-11 |df= }}</ref> These symptoms may lead the victim to present the symptoms as the source of the problem.<ref name=salter/>
Child abuse, especially chronic abuse starting at early ages, has been related to high levels of dissociative symptoms in a clinical sample,<ref name="merckelback">{{cite journal |last1= Merckelbach |first1= H |last2= Muris |first2= P | title = The causal link between self-reported trauma and dissociation: A critical review | journal = Behaviour Research and Therapy | volume = 39 | issue = 3 | pages = 245–54 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11227807 | doi = 10.1016/S0005-7967(99)00181-3| url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0005-7967(99)00181-3 | accessdate = 2008-05-13}}</ref> including amnesia for abuse memories.<ref name=chu>{{cite journal |last=Chu |first=J |last2= Frey |first2= LM |last3= Ganzel |first3= BL |last4= Matthews |first4= JA |date=May 1999 |title=Memories of childhood abuse: Dissociation, amnesia, and corroboration |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=156 |issue=5 |pages=749–55 |pmid = 10327909 |doi=10.1176/ajp.156.5.749|doi-broken-date=2018-03-06 }}</ref> A non-clinical sample of adult women linked increased levels of dissociation to sexual abuse by a significantly older person prior to age 15,<ref name=briere1988>{{cite journal |last1=Briere |first1= J |last2= Runtz |first2= M |title=Symptomatology associated with childhood sexual victimization in a nonclinical adult sample |journal=Child Abuse and Neglect |volume=12 |issue= 1 |pages=51–59 |year=1988 |pmid=3365583 |doi= 10.1016/0145-2134(88)90007-5|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0145-2134(88)90007-5}}</ref> and dissociation has also been [[correlation|correlated]] with a history of childhood physical and sexual abuse.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Briere |first1= J |last2= Runtz |first2= M |title=Augmenting Hopkins SCL scales to measure dissociative symptoms: Data from two nonclinical samples |journal=Journal of Personality Assessment |volume=55 |issue=1–2 |pages=376–9 |year=1990 |pmid=2231257 |doi= 10.1080/00223891.1990.9674075|url=}}</ref> When sexual abuse is examined, the levels of dissociation were found to increase along with the severity of the abuse.<ref name=draijer>{{cite journal |last=Draijer |first=N |last2=Langeland |first2= W |date=March 1999 |title=Childhood trauma and perceived parental dysfunction in the etiology of dissociative symptoms in psychiatric inpatients |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=156 |issue=3 |pages=379–85 |pmid = 10080552 |doi=10.1016/j.biopsych.2003.08.018}}</ref>
A 2012 review article supports the hypothesis that current or recent trauma may affect an individual's assessment of the more distant past, changing the experience of the past and resulting in dissociative states.<ref name="pmid22423434">{{cite journal |last=Stern |first= DB |title=Witnessing across time: Accessing the present from the past and the past from the present |journal=The Psychoanalytic Quarterly |volume=81 |issue=1 |pages=53–81 |date=January 2012 |pmid=22423434 |doi=10.1002/j.2167-4086.2012.tb00485.x |url= }}</ref>
== Psychoactive substances == {{Main|Dissociative drug}} [[Psychoactive drug]]s can often induce a state of temporary dissociation. Substances with dissociative properties include [[ketamine]], [[nitrous oxide]], [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]], [[tiletamine]], [[amphetamine]], [[dextromethorphan]], [[MK-801]], [[phencyclidine|PCP]], [[methoxetamine]], [[Salvia divinorum|salvia]], [[muscimol]], [[atropine]], [[ibogaine]], and [[Minocycline#Central Nervous System|minocycline]].<ref>{{cite book | isbn = 1-57066-053-0 | first = AJ | last = Giannini | title = Drugs of Abuse | edition = 2nd | location = Los Angeles | publisher = Practice Management Information Corp | year = 1997 }}</ref>

[[File:Infamy-address-1.gif|thumb|right|A draft of [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]]'s [[Infamy Speech]], including the President's handwritten annotations]]
'''Drafting''' is the preliminary stage of a written work in which the author begins to develop a more cohesive product. A '''draft document''' is the product the writer creates in the initial stages of the [[writing process]].
In the drafting stage, the author: * develops a more cohesive text * organizes thoughts * explains examples/ideas * uncovers transitions * discovers a central argument/point * elaborates on key ideas
In a book that became popular in the 1950s, ''[[The Elements of Style]]'', famed authors Strunk and White describe the first draft as being a less edited version of the final draft. In their book, Strunk and White say, “the first principle of composition is to foresee or determine the shape of what is to come and pursue that shape.<ref>The Elements of Style Fiftieth Anniversary Edition (2009), p. 15, {{ISBN|978-0-205-63264-0}}</ref>” This shape is the draft that eventually becomes the finished work.
More recently, [[Peter Elbow]], in his book ''Writing Without Teachers'', presents a very different view of the drafting stage in the [[writing process]]. He describes his stance on the writing process, saying “Writing is a way to end up thinking something you couldn’t have started out thinking.<ref>Elbow, Peter. Writing Without Teachers. 2nd ed. New York: Oxford UP, 1973, 1998. p.15</ref>” According to Elbow, the best way to accomplish this is a series of drafts which come together to produce an emerging “center of gravity” that then translates into the main focus on the work. This process should be a holistic process, not a linear process. Elbow’s reasoning behind this concept of multiple drafts follows the idea that, “if he learns to maximize the interaction among his own ideas or points of view, he can produce new ones that didn’t seem available to him.<ref>Elbow, Peter. Writing Without Teachers. 2nd ed. New York: Oxford UP, 1973, 1998. p.50</ref>”
Whether being used as the creation of a less-edited final product (Strunk and White) or as a tool during the prewriting stage (Elbow), drafting is a necessary stage for the writer in the writing process. Having created a draft, the author is then able to move onto the revision.
